repnme.cdata!:
Central Africa - Education for All : Fast
            Track Initiative Education Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education for All : Fast
            Track Initiative Education Sector Development Project for
            Central Africa were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was high, Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Grantee
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: complementing government capacity with
            external service providers and delegated project management
            agreements can be effective in fragile contexts to produce
            results in the short- to medium-term. World Bank teams
            should ensure the establishment of a robust monitoring and
            evaluation (M and E) system allowing for the tracking of
            implementation progress and attribution of outcomes to
            project-financed interventions. In fragile contexts,
            simplicity of project design and tailoring of implementation
            arrangements to government and implementing agency capacity
            help ensure absorption of financing. Close supervision is
            critical in low-capacity contexts, and in particular for
            delegated management arrangements to help promote the
            success of school infrastructure programs. There is high
            value in the World Bank remaining engaged with client
            countries during periods of crisis, including in cases where
            policies require the suspension of project disbursements.

repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Education for
            All - Fast Track Initiative Education Sector Development
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education for All - Fast Track
            Initiative Education Sector Development Project for Central
            African Republic grant will contribute to the implementation
            of phase one of the Government National Education Strategy
            (2008-2011), and aims to improve access to better quality
            primary education. The extension is necessary to provide the
            Ministry of Primary and Secondary Education and Literacy the
            additional time to complete the civil works program,
            particularly the portion of the program that has been
            delegated to Agence d'Execution de Travaux
            d'Interet Publique (AGETIP) for management. In
            addition, it will allow the 2010-2012 teacher cohorts to
            graduate in September 2012. Ministry of Primary and
            Secondary Education and Literacy (MEPSA) has put in place an
            action plan to complete the project fully; particularly it
            has discussed and agreed with AGETIP on an execution
            schedule based on the Bank's findings during the July
            2011 implementation support mission. This will be the first
            extension of the project.

display_title.display_title:
Central African Republic -
            Education for All - Fast Track Initiative Education Sector
            Development Project : restructuring  (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
